key_insight: Classical psychometric tests can be adapted to reliably measure and validate personality-like traits in large instruction-tuned LLMs, and models can be conditioned to mimic specific personality profiles in downstream tasks.
problem_solved: Addresses the lack of a rigorous, validated framework for quantifying, validating, and shaping personality-like behavior in LLMs for evaluation, auditing, and controllability.
method: Adapt established psychometric personality assessments (e.g., questionnaire-style prompts) to elicit and score LLM responses.
Validate reliability and consistency of measurements across large, instruction-tuned models.
Demonstrate controllability by conditioning or fine-tuning models to reproduce target personality profiles and testing transfer to downstream tasks.
impact: Gives AI/ML practitioners a validated toolkit to evaluate and shape conversational style and behavioral traits in LLMs, improving controllability, interpretability, and safer deployment of conversational agents.
visual_elements: Flowchart showing pipeline: psychometric prompt → scoring → reliability validation → personality shaping
Bar chart or heatmap comparing reliability/consistency scores across model families and tuning regimes
Radar (spider) plots comparing Big Five-style trait profiles for baseline vs shaped models (and human benchmarks)
Side-by-side prompt→response examples illustrating before/after personality shaping
paper_title: A psychometric framework for evaluating and shaping personality traits in large language models
paper_authors: Gregory Serapio-García, Mustafa Safdari, Clément Crepy, Luning Sun, Stephen Fitz
